course.subject: LIFS
course.name: Concepts and Issues in Contemporary Biotechnology
course.description: This course will survey the methods and applications of biotechnology, in the aspect related to animals, microbes, agriculture, human health and environment. The consequences of developments in this area will be examined, with emphasis on the aroused great public interest and the increasing demand for the informed debate. For BIOT and BIBU students only.
course.prerequisites: CENG 1600 OR LIFS 2040

reviews.author: fierce_bad_girl
reviews.comment_content:
Aha! A space virgin course.
To be frank even somebody as cynical as I am (see review on LIFS 3160) couldn't find much to get pissed at over this course.

Dr. Ng started with an overview of first generation biotech drugs like insulin and some slightly technical recombinant DNA techniques. He then moved on to student presentations for most of the course, but you could see that he was actually good at what he did - he basically knew everything the presenters were on about off the top of his head and asked critical questions to help us think.

The course was more drug development and business-focused than biochemistry-related, which was a great change from all the technical courses you poor suckers have been doing.
reviews.comment_teaching: He's great! Multidisciplinary, super fast with emails, business-focused and sharp, he's awesome. Worked as head of R&D in the States for 30-odd years. Nothing more to be said.
reviews.comment_grading:
He's super fucking nice. He tried to give half the class an A, the LIFS committee got pissed at him and he crammed absolute grading down their bloody throats.
He gave me two hours worth of career advice and agreed to an interview I was doing for a sociology class.
I fucking love this dude.
The exams were nice and easy, a breeze to blow through, because he says they're designed that way so we get treated better in the hell that is SSCI, HKUST within the context of the ridiculous grade inflation in HKU and CUHK.
reviews.comment_workload:
Not light, I have to say (although I do respect professors who actually give enough fucks about their students to grade all their work).

You can pick to teach an individual or a group (2-3 people) one hour seminar on any aspect of biology you want - lots of people do "Biotech in [insert continent/region]" and present on the big pharma and their drugs and the deals (acquisitions and mergers) that have been made.  
I did an individual seminar because I did not some freerider to go home crying to mommy. It was pretty awesome.

reviews.author: LLLEE
reviews.title: Super BAD grade after changing the lecturers
reviews.comment_content:
Divided into 2 parts:
1st part taught by WK Wong - about biotechnology, plasmids, E.coli., protein expression techniques etc.
2nd part taught by Prof. Chew - about the biotech industry, business, and market examples etc.
reviews.comment_teaching:
For WK Wong, just copy all the notes during the lecture, everyone knows how he teaches from the LIFS2070's experience
For Prof. Chew, his ppt is full of words and he couldn't finish his part but all are tested (even the graph is tested!!! crazy). Don't expect too much from him.
reviews.comment_grading:
I can't believe an 80.xx% overall score is equivalent to a B-?
The worst grading curve for a LIFS course

Attendance: 10/10
1st quiz: 15.xx/20 (MC and TF and fill in the blanks)
2nd quiz: 14.xx/20 (MC and TF)
presentation: 40/50
**Overall: 80.xx/100

Easy exam format means you will lose more marks if you make careless mistakes. Also, they ask about some very minor points which you can hardly recall. Just be careful and be prepared for the minor points.
reviews.comment_workload:
A big part of the grade is contributed by the presentation. So the most workload should be put on the presentation.
I would recommend either you do the job for your teammates or else you will get it ruined by them. I have 2 free-riders (4 random people in a team) in my team who got their part done just before the presentation. Our presentation was overrun by 1 min and we did poorly for the Q&A (one of the free-riders bullshitted representing us, how dare her?), though I think the content is not that bad.
I think if you did not overrun and were able to answer the Q&A confidently (thinking back it is not hard, we know the answer but can't think of that at that time), the marks could be higher than average.

reviews.comment_teaching: I love this inverted learning mode of instruction. We learn the best by working on projects ourselves and articulating to others what we've learnt in our projects. In the meantime, SC Ng will highlight important points in the student presentations, raise important questions for more in-depth discussion, correct our mistakes if we've made any. Overall an all-rounded and practical course.
reviews.comment_grading:
‚úèÔ∏è Midterm: 30%
‚úèÔ∏è Final: 35%
üí¨ Project: 35%

The midterm was a few fill-in-the-blank plus one 26 mix-and-match question. For unknown reason a lot of us didn't do well (considering that was a rather easy exam). Our score ranged from 3 out of 40 to perfect score, and class average was merely 23/40.

Due to the political situation in Hong Kong, the final became an online open-book exam. We were given 3 hours just to complete five fill-in-the-blank questions and one 26 mix-and-match question, and the exam only covered the content taught after the midterm. I believe that was just a special case this year - from what I've heard the final exam used to be very difficult in the past years, and it should be cumulative. SC Ng has been very generous in handling the special situation this year.

üíØ I got 33/40 (Mean = 23.0, SD = 7.8) in the midterm, unknown score in both the presentation and final, ending up in an A.
reviews.comment_workload: Pretty light workload for a life sciences course. It isn't about rote memorization of these tedious biochemical pathways and messy information, but rather the understanding of critical biotech issues, and some key facts and figures that every biotech graduate should remember. The group project does take some time to work on, and SC Ng might even ask you to improve your slides (our group had to revise our slides twice after our first submission). But overall it's a rewarding experience.

reviews.comment_teaching:
I have no idea what Karl Tsim is here for.
But then I am not sure if I have any idea what NG is here for as well.

They are both good storytellers, I'll give them that. Their, very limited, teaching time is enjoyable enough.

This course lets the students learn by teaching, through giving and listening to presentations. So, basically, all class content is taught by fellow students. I appreciate this style of learning, tho I can understand if some are opposed to it.

NG gives important added information after each presentation, so listen up.
reviews.comment_grading:
Class participation (10%)
- attendance, Q&A after each presentation
- discussions on CANVAS

Group project (40%)
-3 randomly assigned students are formed into a group to resent on a topic.
- He briefly talked through each topic in the first two to three lessons.
- He will give very detailed comments and guidelines if you submit a draft early and ask him through email, so basically no difficulty preparing slides at all.

Open book final (50%)
- 1.5hr
- Matching of topics to statements/technologies
-Section 3: Fill in the blanks
- VERY easy, too easy.

reviews.author: hoiyan
reviews.title: useful course
reviews.comment_content:
The lecture is updated and informative that includes information of the newest techniques, introduction of top selling drugs and famous biotech companies. The lecture was in the form of group presentations. Every group was responsible for an assigned topic and then we have 20 minutes to deliver the talk within lesson.

Topics in 17-18 fall includes:
Drugs: Afreeza, remicade,  humira, Herceptin, Avastin, Lucentis, enbrel
Companies: celgene, abbott, gilead, 23&me, novartis, BGI, amgen, roche
techniques: cloning, stem cells, botox, golden rice, cancer immunotherapy, car-T
Others: venture capital, etc.

I guess the topics will be similar for the upcoming semesters but may change with the trend in market.
reviews.comment_teaching: Even most lecture content were delivered through students' presentations, NG also told us lots of supplemental information, and most importantly, what he mentioned in lessons are the key points that appear in the exams, so do attend every lessons and mark things down.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading was quite lenient.

Mid-term examination 30%
Project 20%
Final Examination 50%

I got 27/30 for midterm. Unknown for the project and final. Finally i got a B+. i am satisfied.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is light up till midterm exam, just one present and the midterm was quite easy and straightforward. About 1/3 students got 90% or above. But for the final, it will be a little bit harder since it is accumulative, you will need to study lots of drugs and companies. But i think it's okay if u attended lessons coz then you will have some basic ideas before revising. and the final exam was not difficult either.

reviews.author: qorhvk
reviews.comment_content:
Super useful and interesting. It is heavily based on the presentation given by the students. The professor only teaches like 4 lectures (just add and drop), but I hoped he could do more as his lecture was really enlightening.

He starts with basic biotech issues and concepts: insulin, genentech and current issues in biotech industry. After that, every lecture is about student's presentation. It is supposed to be 20 mins per group (2-3 persons, mostly 2), but if the topic is intriguing, he is indulgent with time. The topic covers from movies related to biotech ethics to current biotech companies and top-selling drugs. It was a meaningful lecture to know more and deeper about the biotech in real life.
reviews.comment_teaching: He is multi-disciplined, kind and intellectual. A bit of disappointment that he gets to teach only 4 lectures. He welcomes students with career woes so feel free to talk with him. He is not reluctant to help and give advice to students at anytime.
reviews.comment_grading:
Not sure about the grading but I think he tried to give as many of A and B as possible.

Midterm 30
Presentation 20
Final 50

Final was not shown on canvas so not sure about it but I got pretty good grades.
reviews.comment_workload:
The presentation workload, I believe, depends on what topic you chose and when it is. The presentation is from very first week to very last week, so select the topic smartly according to your schedule.
Midterm workload was okay. Actually he gave lots of hints about what would be tested, and a lot of people got almost 100. I think thats why he did not mention anything in the final though.
Final workload was huge. All the companies and drugs.. Take some time to study thoroughly.
